repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Urban development - Poverty
            reduction and promoting growth for urbanization

abstracts.cdata!:
This report on poverty reduction and
            promoting growth for urbanization as an aspect of urban
            development in Tunisia claims the World Bank aims to respond
            to both aspects of the challenge posed by urbanization by
            firstly, helping governments prepare proactively for new
            urban growth and, secondly, supporting improved service
            delivery for urban poor. In view of these goals, the
            institution will provide support for urban development
            through five types of activities, namely, 1) management,
            financing and management of cities; 2) improving urban
            poverty and poor housing; 3) cities and economic growth; 4)
            planning, housing and urban land; and 5) urban and disaster
            management and climate change.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Regional Development in the
            Copan Valley Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Regional Development in
            the Copan Valley Project for Honduras were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the hiring of specialized technical
            assistance during the project design and execution stages
            was critical to address potential challenges faced by the
            project in terms of technical expertise. The selected
            partner organizations had a proven track record and abundant
            field experience regarding their respective domains of
            expertise in conservation of archeological monuments and
            parks and income generation activities. In sharp contrast
            with other models of tourism development, cultural tourism
            opened opportunities for income generation activities for
            the poor, particularly in 'culturally reach'
            communities. Cultural tourism enabled indigenous communities
            to unbundle their knowledge and traditions as income
            generation assets, demonstrating its potential as a
            legitimate business area for the Bank and client governments
            to move forward their poverty reduction agendas.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Regional Development in the
            Copan Valley Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Regional Development in the Copan Valley Project is to
            achieve sustainable tourism development based on the
            cultural and natural patrimony of the Copan Valley and the
            surrounding areas which will, as a result, create investment
            opportunities for the private sector, foster employment, and
            reduce poverty in one of the poorest regions of Honduras. To
            increase economic growth, the Government is pursuing a
            robust tourism development strategy that capitalizes on its
            many exceptional natural and cultural resources. In 2002,
            tourism grew by 20 percent with more than 800,000 visitors.
            The Government seeks to increase this number to one million
            visitors by 2005 and be a regional leader in tourism by
            2021. Project components are: 1) integrated development of
            archeological parks and sites, will create and Archeological
            Tourism Circuit by financing tourism infrastructure and
            training in participatory management; 2) income generation
            opportunities, will implement a program of formation for
            populations in the project areas, particularly the very
            poor; and 3) institutional development, will design and
            implement institutional strengthening and communications,
            and enhancements to the Project Coordination Unit (PCU) and
            monitoring and evaluation.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Regional Development in the
            Copan Valley Project - environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment focuses on
            the parks' tourism development, infrastructure
            development, and productive components under the Regional
            Development in the Copan Valley Project, whose main
            objective is to develop an archaeological/ecological tourist
            route, within protected areas in Honduras. The project
            design will take into consideration appropriate
            environmental protection, to include as well appropriate
            site selection for the construction works, roads, and access
            roads rehabilitation, installation of power lines, and
            facilities at large. The criteria for site selection should
            take into account the national, state, and municipal
            regulations to prevent adversity on rural lands, road
            alignments, and land potentially prone to flooding,
            earthquakes, or soil erosion, while existing flora and fauna
            should be protected within its natural habitats. In
            addition, land tenure issues that may potentially hamper
            land acquisition due to legal problems, should be considered
            early on, including any social issue that may arise.
            Construction works will comply with specifications contained
            in the bidding documents, which stipulate the following
            activities within the project area, will be banned:
            deforestation; fires; hunting, and/or fishing activities;
            degradation of natural vegetation; and, damage on
            architectural, or cultural heritage sites. Solid waste
            disposal shall follow strict environmental regulations, to
            be disposed of at selected landfills (located at a minimum
            of 300 meters from rivers or wetlands), or, if lubricants,
            oil, or metals, appropriately separated, and recycled or
            stored in appropriate bins, respectively. Protective
            barriers should be installed to contain soil erosion,
            particularly along roadsides, slopes, and land excavation
            perimeters, while continual spraying of construction
            surfaces should control air pollution. Further mitigation
            addresses traffic safety measures, noise abatement, public
            awareness campaigns, and environmental monitoring, and
            supervision activities.
